questions.text: Which of the following is an example of multiphasic screening?

choices.text: Chest X-ray for TB in large populations
Pap smear in women above 40 years
Random blood sugar during antenatal visits

questions.solution:
Annual health checkups are an example of multiphasic screening.

Types of screening:

  1. Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination with a large number of people at one time. Example- Annual health checkups.
  2. High-risk or selective screening is done on high-risk groups. Example- MRI screening of breast done annually in 25-year old women with BRCA 1, BRCA 2 mutations in a first-degree relative.
  3. Mass screening is a screening of a whole or large population like using a chest X-ray for TB screening in large populations. It is done for diseases with high prevalence.

questions.text: A research scholar is preparing to do a prospective cohort study in a hospital to evaluate the association of H. pylori with inflammatory bowel disease. Which of the following measures must she take, before starting the study?

choices.text: Enrol all patients taking proton pump inhibitors
Enrol all patients on whom endoscopy was done
Exclude all patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease
Exclude all patients with positive urea breath test for H. pylori

questions.solution:
All patients diagnosed with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) must be excluded from a prospective cohort study, as the study progresses from cause to effect. The study begins before the disease under study has occurred.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text:
Match the following.
Data Scale of data
1) Number of cancer patients in a hospital  a) Discrete data
2) Height and weight b) Interval scale data
3) Blood pressure measurements c) Ratio scale data
4) Temperature measurement in Celsius  
5) Temperature measurement in Kelvin
questions.solution:
The number of cancer patients in a hospital is an example of discrete data. They can only take certain values and none in between.

The temperature measured in the Celsius scale is an example of interval scale data. Such data are arranged in a meaningful order but they can not have an absolute zero value. For example, 80 degree celcius to not twice as hot as 40 degree celcius and 0 degree celcius does not indicate an absolute abscence of heat.

Height and weight, blood pressure and temperature in the Kelvin scale are examples of ratio scale data. Such data are arranged in a meaningful order and the scales they are measured in have absolute zero value. For example, a temperature of 0 kelvin indicates an absolute abscense of heat.

Height and weight, blood pressure, and temperature are examples of continuous data as they can take any values between limits or a range.

Related Pearl: Scales of data measurement

Data can be quantitative (numerical values) or qualitative (types, labels).

Quantitative data can be discrete variables or continuous variables.

 

Description

Example

Discrete data

Can take certain values and none in between

Number of cancer patients in a hospital. 

Continuous data

Can take any value usually in between limits or a range. 

Most biomedical data is continuous.

Height, weight, blood pressure, etc.

 

Data always forms one of four scales of measurement – nominal, ordinal, interval, or ratio scales (mnemonic: NOIR):

 

Nominal Scale Data

Ordinal Scale Data

Interval Scale Data

Ratio Scale Data

Example

Male/female; red/green; sub-urban/rural

Students ranked 1st/2nd/3rd in their class. 

A customer feedback survey using terms like very good, good, poor and very poor or the Likert Scale.

Severity of a disease as mild, moderate, severe

 

 Measurements on the celsius scale. Pulse rate; 

Notes

Have no quantitative value.

They have no order or ratio. 

Arranged in a meaningful order.

No size interval is defined

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Example: Temperature in Celsius. If temperature in A is 40 deg Celsius and that in B is 20 deg Celsius, then A is 20 deg Celsius hotter than B (taking difference)

Does not have an absolute zero.

For example, Celsius scale has no such thing as “no temperature”. So the value cannot be zero.

Arranged in a meaningful order with a well defined size interval.

Eg: A pulse rate has well defined intervals and is meaningful in comparison. A 100/min pulse is exactly twice of 50 beats/min.

 

Has an absolute zero.

Eg: There can be a value of zero for pulse.

Type

Qualitative

Qualitative

Quantitative

Quantitative

questions.text:
Which of the following is a second-generation intra-uterine device?
  1. Lippes loop
  2. Mirena
  3. Nova T
  4. Progestasert
  5. Cu-T-380 Ag
questions.solution:
Nova T and Cu-T-380 Ag are second-generation intrauterine devices (IUD). 

IUD is a contraceptive method inserted into the uterine cavity. The different generations of IUDs include:

  • First-generation IUDs – inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop
  • Second-generation IUDs - medicated with metallic elements like copper eg: Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-375
  • Third-generation IUDs – hormone-containing IUDs like progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20)

questions.text: Which method is most appropriate when suitable land for waste disposal is available?
questions.solution:
Controlled tipping is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is available.

In this method, waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the day. This method is also called a sanitary landfill. Chemical, bacteriological and physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60 degrees Celsius within 7 days.

Methods used for controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method
  • Ramp method
  • Area method

Sewage farming is also a method of sewage disposal in places where sufficient and suitable land is available. It is also called land treatment or broad irrigation.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man is brought to you following an accident. How would you discard his blood-soaked dressing material?

choices.text: Pour 1% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Pour 5% hypochlorite on the dressing material and send for incineration
Put the dressing material directly in an appropriate bag and send for incineration
Pour 10% non chlorinated chemicals on the dressing material and send for incineration

questions.solution:
The blood-soaked dressing material should be disposed of in a non-chlorinated yellow bag and sent for incineration. Pretreatment is not a requisite for incinerating soiled waste.

Items that require pretreatment with non-chlorinated chemicals before incineration:

  • Used blood bags
  • Other infectious plastic and liquid wastes 
  • Laboratory cultures, stocks, or specimens of microorganisms
  • Live or attenuated vaccines
  • Human and animal cell cultures used in research
  • Dishes, and devices used for cultures

questions.solution:
The logo given above represents radiation waste.

Other logos:

questions.text: What is the p value?

choices.text: Probability of declaring a significant difference when there is none in reality
Probability of declaring a significant difference when it is actually present
Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present
Probability of not declaring a significant difference when actually it is present

questions.solution:
p-value can be defined as the probability of declaring a significant difference when there is none in reality.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: Which of the following is a lower-pressure membrane process for treatment of water?
questions.solution:
Microfiltration is a lower-pressure membrane process used for the treatment of water.

Membrane processes are employed in the large scale treatment of water. They are classified as high-pressure processes and lower-pressure processes. 

  • High-pressure processes:
    • Reverse osmosis - Rejects monovalent ions and organic molecules of molecular weight > 50 daltons. It is most commonly used for desalination of brackish water and sea water. The membrane pore size is < 0.002 µm.
    • Nanofiltration - Allows monovalent ions such as sodium or potassium to pass but rejects a high proportion of divalent ions like calcium and magnesium and some higher molecular weight organics. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.001 – 0.01 µm. 
  • Lower-pressure processes:
    • Ultrafiltration - Rejects organic molecules of molecular weight > 800 daltons. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.002 - 0.003 µm.
    • Microfiltration - Rejects colloidal and suspended material. It does not separate molecules and is usually used before reverse osmosis. The membrane pore size ranges from 0.01 – 12 µm.

questions.text: Among the given options, what can be the likely value of the coefficient of correlation between infant mortality rate and economic status?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the coefficient of correlation between infant mortality rate and economic status (r) is likely to be -0.8. 

It is known that low economic status is associated with a high infant mortality rate. This indicates a negative correlation. However, the infant mortality rate is also influenced by other factors, indicating a moderate correlation (not equal to 1). This makes -0.8 the most likely value of correlation.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, vomiting, and abdominal pain for 4 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is given below. Which of the following is true about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

choices.text: Keeps its body horizontal while feeding

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing ring form/ early trophozoites in erythrocytes are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. It is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. They have spotted wings.

They breed in clean water. Their larva has no siphon tube and lies parallel to the undersurface of water. They tend to sit with their heads low and their rare ends raised high, especially when feeding.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Eggs: 100-250.

questions.text: What is the surveillance reporting system used by the WHO?
questions.solution:
The surveillance reporting system used by the WHO is the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

The WHO collects and disseminates epidemiological information on diseases subject to International Health Regulations. It is done through an Automatic Telex Reply Service (ATRS) and the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

questions.text: A study found that the incidence of bladder carcinoma is 5 times higher in smokers than in non smokers. Calculate the attributable risk.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the attributable risk (AR) is 80%.

Taking the incidence of disease in non-exposed as x, the incidence of disease in exposed would be 5x. 

Attributable risk (AR) would be given as [(5x - x)/5x] x 100 = 80%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct ascending order of the Maslow’s hierarchy of needs?
questions.solution:
Maslow’s hierarchy of needs was suggested by psychologist Abraham Maslow. It is a motivational theory in psychology where human needs are arranged according to hierarchy in a five-level pyramid.

He suggested that the higher needs can be fulfilled only once the lower needs are fulfilled.

questions.text: As part of the national maternity benefit scheme, you have been tasked with conducting a study in a community of 5000 people.  What is the expected number of pregnant women in this community if the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people?
questions.solution:
The expected number of pregnant females in the given community would be 165.

Step 1: In the given question, the crude birth rate is 30 per 1000 people i.e 30 children are born from pregnant mothers for every 1000 people. Therefore there are 30 pregnant females per 1000 population.

Step 2: Since the total population is 5000, the total no of pregnant females = 5000 x 30/1000 = 150 

Step 3: Since some pregnancies may not result in live births (abortions and stillbirths), a correction factor of 10% should be added to avoid the underestimation of the number of pregnancies. Pregnancy wastage (i.e 10% of total live births) =10 x 150/100=15.

Step 4: Total pregnant females = total live births + pregnancy wastage = 150+15=165.

questions.text: Millennium Development Goals were based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
Millennium Development Goals were based on the United Nations Millennium Declaration. 

The Millennium Development Goals were eight development goals to be achieved by 2015 and were established at the turn of the millennium in 2000 by the UN.

It came to an end in December 2015 and was replaced by the 17 Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

On 1st January 2016, the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 agenda officially came into force.

The five P's of the new agenda are: 

  • People
  • Planet
  • Prosperity
  • Peace
  • Partnership

The eight Millennium Development Goals are:

questions.text: Which of the following is not an aryl organo-phosphate insecticide?
questions.solution:
Malathion is an alkyl organophosphate insecticide. It is used as an ultra-low volume spray in mosquito control.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

questions.text:
A randomised control trial is being conducted in patients with direct inguinal hernia, to compare the outcomes of a new surgery 'A' and the gold standard surgery 'B'.
The p value of this trial is found to be 0.04. What can we conclude from this?

choices.text: Type II error is small and we can accept the findings of the study
The probability of false negative conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%
The power of the study to detect the difference between operation A and B is 96%
The probability of a false positive conclusion that operation A is better than B is 4%

questions.solution:
Since the p-value of the study is found to be 0.04, we can infer that the probability of a false positive conclusion that the operation A is better than B is 4%.

In this scenario, the p value is 0.04 which makes it, by convention, statistically significant. We can reject the null hypothesis and accept the alternative hypothesis that operation A is better than operation B.

  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.

  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: The National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is planning to study the natural history of COVID-19. Which of the following studies can be used?
questions.solution:
Longitudinal studies are useful to study the natural history of a disease.

It is also used to identify risk factors, and to find the incidence rate. In longitudinal studies, observations are repeated in the same population over a prolonged period of time by follow-up examinations. Their disadvantage is that they are difficult to organize and take a very long time.

questions.text: Which committee had recommended a bachelor degree in medical education for rural health services?

choices.text: High-level expert group on universal health coverage

questions.solution:

questions.text: Identify the following graphical representation of data.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a frequency polygon. It is obtained by joining the midpoints of histogram blocks. It is used to diagrammatically represent frequency distribution.

Scattergram is a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along two axes. The pattern of the resulting points reveals any correlation that may be present. The below image shows a scattergram.

A line diagram is a type of chart that displays information as a series of data points called 'markers' connected by straight line segments. It is usually used to study time trends.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A researcher wanted to calculate the mean age of onset of type II diabetes mellitus in a population. He got a sample mean of 45. To measure the extent of deviation from the population mean, which of the following should he use?
questions.solution:
The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population means.

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about random errors?

choices.text: Systematic errors are different from random errors

questions.solution:
Random errors are not causes of bias. 

Random error arises when a value of the sample measurement diverges, due to chance alone, from that of the true population value. They can never be completely eliminated. 

Sources of random errors are individual biological variations, sampling errors, and measurement errors.

Systematic errors are also called biases. They are different from random errors.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: While collecting data on which of the following variables would median not be the preferred measure of central tendency?
questions.solution:
Blood pressure usually forms a normal symmetrical distribution for which mean is the preferred measure of central tendency.

Distributions of survival time, incubation period and health expenses have the probability of having extreme values, i.e., outliers. Thus, they form skewed distributions and in such cases, median is the preferred measure of central tendency.

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

questions.text: Which article of the Indian Constitution confers Right to Life to the citizens of India?
questions.solution:
The Right to Life is given in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution.

Option A: Article 11 defines the right of the parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law.

Option C: Article 23 defines the prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

Option D: Article 25 defines the freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion.

questions.text:
Ten successive readings of hemoglobin level of a single sample measured by a new method are given below. The hemoglobin level measured by the previous standard test was 10.2. What is true regarding the new method?

Readings: 9.4, 10.4, 9.6, 9.1, 10.8, 12.1, 10.1, 9.8, 9.2, and 9.5.
questions.solution:
The new method for measuring hemoglobin has high validity and low reliability.

The new test doesn’t give the same values on repeat testing, thus it has low reliability. The mean value of all the readings is 10. The mean is close to the value of 10.2, which is obtained from the standard test, making the validity high.

The validity of a test implies that the test must give correct and accurate results. It represents the closeness to a true/ actual value.

The reliability of a test implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

Related Pearl: Repeatability of a Screening Test

Repeatability is an attribute of an ideal screening test. It is also called reliability, precision, or reproducibility. It implies that the test must give consistent results when repeated on the same individual or material, under the same conditions.

It depends upon three factors:

A. Observer variation

  • All observations are subjected to variations.
  • Intra-observer variations or within-observer variations are when a single observer takes two measurements in the same subject, at the same time and obtained two different results.
  • Inter-observer variations or between-observer variations are when two different observers obtain different results on the same subject or material.
  • They are minimized by standardization of procedures, intensive training of observers, and making use of more observers.

B. Biological variation

  • It is also called subject variation.
  • They are due to changes in the parameters observed, variations in the perceptions of symptoms by patients, and regression to the mean where there is a tendency of values to be at either extreme of the distribution.

C. Errors relating to technical methods is due to the following:

  • Defective instruments
  • Erroneous calibration
  • Faulty reagents
  • Incorrect methods

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

choices.text: Few of their responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers
They should have formal education at least up to class 10
A population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA
They have to procure ORS, OCPs, IFA tablets from CHC

questions.solution:
Accredited social health activist (ASHA) workers do not need to procure supplies from CHCs. They only act as depot holders for certain essential supplies so that they are readily available to their community.

These essential supplies may include ORS, contraceptives, iron-folic acid tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral contraceptive pills, condoms, etc. 

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste?
questions.solution:
Microwaving is a low-heat system for the treatment of biomedical waste.

The heating systems used for the treatment and disposal of biomedical waste are:

Low-heat system High-heat system

Autoclaving: Uses steam. It is of two types-

  1. Gravity flow autoclave 
  2. Vacuum autoclave

Microwaving: Uses moist heat and steam generated by microwave energy

Incineration: Waste is destroyed/denatured under high temperatures 

Plasma pyrolysis: Waste is treated at high temperatures under controlled conditions to form gases that are subjected to combustion in the secondary chamber

Hydroclaving: The waste is subjected to indirect heating by applying steam to the outer jacket

Dry heat sterilization: Waste sharps are treated using dry heat at a temperature >185 C for 150 minutes

questions.text: Which of the following can be estimated using Horrock’s apparatus?

choices.text: Both free and combined chlorine levels

questions.solution:
The Horrock’s apparatus is used to determine the chlorine demand of water.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a use of epidemiology?
questions.solution:
Ensuring community participation is not the use of epidemiology. Community participation is a principle of primary health care.

Uses of epidemiology:

  • To study the rise and fall of disease in populations
  • Community diagnosis
  • Planning and evaluation
  • Evaluation of individual’s risks and chances
  • Syndrome identification
  • Completing the natural history of disease
  • Searching for causes and risk factors

questions.text: A screening test was carried out among 114 people out of which 15 have a disease. The test showed 22 people tested positive for the disease among which 14 actually had the disease. What is the sensitivity of the test?
questions.solution:
The sensitivity of the above screening test is 93%.

The given data is represented below

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

14(TP)

8(FP)

22

Test -

1(FN)

91(TN)

92

Total

15(TP+FN)

99(FP+TN)

114

TP- true positive, FP- false positive, FN- false negative, TN- true negative

Sensitivity is given as TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 14/15 = 93%.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of bias in a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Hawthorne bias is not seen in case-control studies. This bias occurs when the subjects change their attitude/ actions while under observation. This distorts the results of the cohort or experimental studies.

The bias that are seen in the case-control study are:

  1. Confounding
  2. Recall bias
  3. Selection bias
  4. Berkesonian bias
  5. Interviewer's bias

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

questions.text: Case fatality rate is ______.

choices.text: Killing power of a disease in time
Killing power of a disease with no time interval

questions.solution:
Case fatality rate reflects the killing power of a disease with no specific time interval.

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A patient with fever and mucosal bleeding is diagnosed with dengue fever. Which of the following is false about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

choices.text: Development of larva from egg does not require water
It has a striped body pattern

questions.solution:
Dengue fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. The conversion from the egg stage to the larval stage of this mosquito requires water.

Eggs of any mosquito species do not survive without water. But the eggs of Aedes mosquitoes lie dormant in dry conditions for up to about nine months. They can hatch if exposed to favourable conditions such as water and food.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: What is total communication used for?
questions.solution:
The philosophy of total communication is used in the education of hearing-impaired children.

It requires the incorporation of aural, oral, and manual modes of communication for effective communication with and among hearing-impaired people.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a morbidity indicator?
questions.solution:
Years of potential life lost is not a morbidity indicator. It is a mortality indicator. It is the years of potential life lost through premature death.

Notification rates, spells of sickness and incidence are examples of morbidity indicators. 

Related Pearl: Mortality and morbidity indicators in epidemiology

Mortality Indicators

Morbidity Indicators

Universal indicators:

  • Crude death rate
  • Life expectancy
  • Age-specific death rates
  • Disease-specific mortality rate
  • Proportional mortality rate
  • Case fatality rate
  • Years of potential life lost
  • Adult mortality rate

Maternal and child-related indicators:

  • Infant mortality rate
  • Child death rate
  • Under-5 proportionate mortality rate
  • Maternal mortality rate
  • Incidence and Prevalence
  • Notification rates
  • Attendance rates at OPD
  • Admission, discharge & re-admission rates
  • Duration of stay in hospital
  • Spells of sickness or absence from work or school

questions.text: You are tasked with conducting a health and wellness survey of the employees of your hospital. Which of the following scales will you not use to classify their socio-economic statuses?
questions.solution:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Scales that have been used for SES are:

  • Udai Pareek scale
  • Kuppuswamy scale
  • Radhukar scale
  • Jalota scale
  • Shirvastava scale
  • Bharadwaj scale
  • Kulshestra scale
  • Hollingshead scale.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

questions.text: The incidence of a disease is 8 per 1000 population with an average duration of 3 years. The prevalence is ________.
questions.solution:
Prevalence = 8/1000 (Incidence) x 3 (Mean Duration of Disease)= 24/1000 population

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: A study is being conducted on anaemia in pregnancy. A normal distribution curve with a mean haemoglobin level of 10.6 gm/dL with a standard deviation of 2 gm/dL is obtained. Below what level would 5% of the women in the group have their haemoglobin values?
questions.solution:
5% of the pregnant women in this group will have their haemoglobin levels below 7.31 g/dL.

Solution:
Given Data :

  • Mean: 10.6 g/dL
  • Standard deviation : 2 g/dL

Step 1:

According to the empirical rule of a normal distribution, 95% of the population fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean, i.e., mean ± 2SD. 
This implies that the remaining 5% lie outside 2 SD, i.e. 2.5% below 2 SD and 2.5% above 2 SD. 
Therefore , Mean - 2SD = 10.6 − 2 (2) 
                                    = 10.6 − 4 
                                    = 6.6 g/dL 
Thus, 2.5% of pregnant women have Hb levels below 6.6 g/dL.

However, the question asks about 5% and not 2.5%. So options C and D have been ruled out.

Now Let's move to the next step.

Step 2:

According to the empirical rule of a normal distribution, 68% of the population fall within 1 standard deviation of the mean, i.e., mean±1SD. 
This implies that the remaining 32% lie outside 1 SD, i.e., 16% below 1 SD and 16% above 1 SD. 
The value of mean−1 SD is 8.6 g/dL (i.e. 10.6 − 2) 
Thus, 16% of pregnant women have Hb levels below 8.6 g/dL.

so now option A is ruled out 

Step 3:

The value for 5% must lie between the values where 2.5% and 16% of the population lie, i.e., between 6.6g/dL and 8g/dL. Only option B, 7.31 g/dL, satisfies this condition.

Hence, 5% of pregnant women have their Hb levels below 7.31 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A multipurpose worker is spraying herbicides on aquatic plants as part of vector control measures in your area. Which of the following water-related diseases can be controlled by this approach?
questions.solution:
Filariasis (caused by B.malayi) is transmitted by Mansonia species of mosquito that breeds in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation. It can be controlled by the use of herbicides to destroy aquatic vegetation.

Water-related diseases are classified as:

Category

Examples
Water-borne diseases

Caused by ingestion of water contaminated by human or animal faeces, or urine containing pathogenic bacteria or viruses.

ex: Cholera, typhoid, amoebic and bacillary dysentery, and other diarrhoeal diseases.
Water-washed diseases

Caused by poor personal hygiene.

ex: Scabies, trachoma, flea-, lice- and tick-borne diseases, in addition to the majority of waterborne diseases (which are also water-washed).
Water-based diseases

Caused by parasites found in intermediate organisms living in water.

ex: Dracunculiasis, schistosomiasis and some other helminths.

 
Water-related diseases transmitted by insect vectors

Caused by vectors that breed in water

ex: Dengue, filariasis, malaria, onchocerciasis, trypanosomiasis and yellow fever.

questions.text: What percentage of GDP was spent on public health in 2020?
questions.solution:
The total public health expenditure is around 1.25% percentage of India's GDP (National Health Profile 2020 report).

The National Health Policy, 2017 states the aim to increase this to around 2.5% by 2025.

questions.text: Out of 100 women who took oral contraceptive pills for contraception, 10 women got pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl index?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 5 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10. There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Hence, pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per HWY. 

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Which curve from the given image reflects a better test?
questions.solution:
Test A is the best test among the four given, as it has the highest sensitivity and the lowest false positive rate (100-specificity).

A receiver operating characteristic curve(ROC) is obtained by plotting a test's true positive rate (sensitivity) against its false-positive rate ( 100- specificity) for different diagnostic cut-off points. 

The shape of the curve reflects the quality of the test. The better the test, the more it moves to the upper left (more the area under the curve). For a good test, sensitivity comes close to 100% on the y-axis, and the false positive rate comes close to 0% on the x-axis.

questions.text: ECG findings detecting the myocardial infarction obtained from the department of cardiology are given in the table below. Which of the following is true with regard to the below table?

choices.text: Sensitivity is the same as specificity
PPV is the same as NPV

questions.solution:
In the above scenario, PPV is the same as NPV.

  MI Present MI Absent
Positive ECG 300(TP) 100(FP)
Negative ECG 25(FN) 75(TN)

Predictive value of a positive test (PPV) 

= TP/(TP + FP) x 100 = 300/(300+100) x 100= 75 %

Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)

= TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 75/(25+75) x 100 = 75 %

Hence PPV = NPV

In this scenario, sensitivity is 92% and the specificity is 43% as per the following calculation,

Sensitivity = TP/(TP + FN) x 100 = 300/(300+25) x100 = 92%

Specificity = TN/(FP + TN) x 100 = 75/(100+75) x100 = 43%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: All the following are the characteristics of waste that can be incinerated except:
questions.solution:
Only waste material containing <5% of noncombustible solids can be incinerated. Wastes that are incinerated go in the yellow bag.

Waste products with the following characteristics can be incinerated:

  • Combustible matter >60%
  • Non-combustible solid <5%
  • Non-combustible fine <20%
  • Low heating volume
  • Moisture content <30%.

questions.text: Which of the following practices is covered under the COPRA act?
questions.solution:
Consumer Protection Act or COPRA was instituted in 1986 and deals with consumer rights.

It recognizes six rights of the consumers, which are:

  • Right to safety
  • Right to be informed
  • Right to be heard
  • Right to choose
  • Right to seek redressal
  • Right to consumer education

questions.text: As an epidemiologist, you are investigating an outbreak of cholera. What is the minimum free residual chlorine level that should be maintained in pipelines to prevent further spread of the outbreak?
questions.solution:
The minimum level of free residual chlorine to be maintained in pipelines following an outbreak of cholera is 0.5 mg/litre.

After a disaster (such as a flood), the water bodies are contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of faeces in drinking bodies increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of free residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is, therefore, higher i.e. 0.7-0.9 mg/litre.

Minimum recommended free residual chlorine levels:

  • Cholera epidemic: 0.5 mg/litre
  • Disaster/ Natural calamities: 0.7 - 0.9 mg/litre
