questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about systematic reviews?
questions.solution:
Meta-analysis is not always performed in systematic reviews.

A systematic review is the process of locating and synthesizing the research on a particular question using organized, transparent, and replicable procedures. It ranks high in the hierarchy of evidence in medicine.

Steps of a systematic review:

  • The research question is formulated. It is always focused.
  • The literature on studies is always found and appraised after criteria of eligibility are established.
  • Meta-analysis is usually done in a systematic review for quantification but it is not compulsory.

These steps are depicted in the diagram below.

questions.text: A study conducted among smokers shows that 80% of the cases of lung cancer are due to cigarette smoking. Which of the following variables indicates this?
questions.solution:
Attributable risk indicates to what extent the disease under study can be attributed to the exposure. Here, cigarette smoking is attributed to be the cause of 80% of lung cancers in smokers.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of a cohort study?

choices.text: Natural history of disease can be studied

questions.solution:
Hawthorne effect is a disadvantage of cohort studies where people change or alter their behaviour during the course of the study, which affects the outcome and distorts the results.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

questions.text: You are conducting a randomised clinical trial to see if a new drug 'A' has better efficacy than the standard drug 'B', in patients with grade III hypertension. While analysing the results of this study, you conclude that no difference exists between the two. But in reality, a difference between them truly exists. What type of error are you making?
questions.solution:
Type II errors are when an alternative hypothesis is rejected when it is true.

In this scenario, the null hypothesis is that there is no difference and the alternative hypothesis is that there is a difference.

We failed to reject the null hypothesis that says there is no difference, and so we are making a type II error. In other words, we have rejected the alternative hypothesis that there is an difference when it is true.

Related Pearl: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

  • A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.
  • It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.
  • If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.
  • It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

  • The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.
  • In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.
  • A null hypothesis is represented by H0.
  • If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

  • If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.
  • When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.
  • By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.
  • If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.
  • Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

  • The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.
  • It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.
  • From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.
  • This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.
  • It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.
  • The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.
  • Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

  • The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.
  • It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.
  • If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.
  • The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

  • The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.
  • It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.
  • By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.
  • Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.
  • A test's power will increase in the following conditions:
    • If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.
    • If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.
    • If sampling error decreases.
    • If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text:
Match the following methods of mosquito control to the appropriate examples.
Method of control Example
l.Biological control a.Larvicidal oil
ll.Genetic control b.Sex distortion
lll.Chemical control c.Source reduction
lV.Environmental control d.Barbados millions

choices.text: I – a, II – b, III – c, IV – d
I – b, II – d, III – c, IV – a
I – c, II – a, III – b, IV – d
I – d, II – b, III – a, IV – c

questions.solution:
The correctly matched methods of mosquito control are:

Method of control Example
Biological control Barbados millions
Genetic control Sex distortion
Chemical control Larvicidal oil
Environmental control Source reduction

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: An outbreak of viral hepatitis A was reported from a town between June and September of a particular year. The peak of the outbreak occurred in July. What is this an example of?
questions.solution:
This outbreak of viral hepatitis A is an example of a common source, multiple exposure type of epidemic.

The incubation period of hepatitis A is approximately 28 days (range 15 to 50 days). In this scenario, the cases of viral hepatitis A have occurred over a period from June to September (120 days) which is more than one incubation period of the disease. This is suggestive of multiple exposures from a common source.

If the period of the outbreak falls within one incubation period, then the type of epidemic is common source ,single exposure or point source epidemic.

Difference between single exposure and multiple exposure epidemics:

  Common source, single exposure epidemic Common source, multiple exposure epidemic
Nature of exposure Single, brief exposure Multiple, continuous or intermittent exposures for a prolonged time
Nature of epidemic Explosive with clustering of cases within a short interval of time Less chance of clustering of cases within short interval of time
Duration of epidemic Falls <1 incubation period of a particular disease Extends >1 incubation period of a particular disease
Example An epidemic of food poisoning  Outbreak of cholera

Propagated epidemic results from person to person transmission of the infectious agent over a prolonged duration of time. For e.g. Polio epidemic, COVID-19.

Note: Hepatitis A epidemic is generally an example of a propagated epidemic. However, it does not always follow this pattern. In the given scenario, since the outbreak lasts for a short duration of 3 months (about 3 incubation periods for hepatitis A), it is considered to be a point source, multiple exposure outbreak.

questions.text: The IQ scores of your study population form a bell-shaped curve. How much of the population falls between the median (Mdn) and Mdn + 1 S.D?
questions.solution:
34% or 0.34 of the population in a normal distribution falls between the median and median plus one standard deviation.

The IQ values form a bell-shaped curve, which is seen in normal symmetric distributions.

According to the empirical rule of normal distributions, 68% of the distribution falls within 1 standard deviation of the mean, i.e., mean ± 1 SD covers 68% of the distribution.

Now, in a normal distribution, mean = median. Therefore, this 68% includes values from median -1SD to median +1SD.

The question asks about the percentage that falls under median +1SD, which would be half of 68%, that is 34% or 0.34.

Below is the graphical representation of the question. The question is asking to calculate the shaded region in the graph.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: What are migration studies used to evaluate?

choices.text: Socio-demographic reasons for migration of a population
Prevalence of diseases in a population
Environmental and genetic factors of a disease in a population
Incidence of disease in the immigrant population

questions.solution:
Migration studies are used to evaluate the role of genetic and environmental factors of a disease in a population.

The two methods used are:

  • Comparing disease and death rates of migrants with kin who stayed at home
  • Comparing disease and death rates of migrants with the local population of the host country

Limitations of these studies:

  • Non-randomization of these groups
  • Environmental factors may act only up to a certain age
  • Not useful for diseases with long incubation periods

questions.text: The uppermost and lowermost values of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie are called the:
questions.solution:
The uppermost and lowermost limits of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie are called the confidence limits.

The difference between upper and lower confidence limits is called the confidence interval.

Related Pearl: Confidence Limits and Interval

Confidence limits are the upper and lower limits of standard errors within which a parameter value is expected to lie.

Generally, 95% confidence limits are used and they are approximately equal to the sample mean plus or minus two standard errors, i.e., 95% confidence limits = Sample mean (x̄) ± 2 standard errors.

The general formula is confidence limits = x̄ ± zσ x̄. 

  • Where z is 3 for 99.7% Cl
  • z is 2 for 95% Cl
  • z is 1 for 68% Cl

The difference between upper and lower confidence limits is called the confidence interval. Since the standard error will decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size, the width of the confidence interval will also decrease in proportion to the square root of the sample size.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at her house. How many visits should an ASHA worker make post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, where the woman has had a home delivery, an ASHA worker would make 7 visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother.

Home visits of ASHA workers post delivery:

  • 7 visits after home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 5 visits after cesarean section delivery, first visit on day 7, and thereafter 4 visits till day 42

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: What is a Punnett square used for?
questions.solution:
A Punnett square is a diagram used to predict the probability of a particular genotype in an offspring.

It is a standard tool for genetic counselors. The image given below shows a Punnett square.

questions.text: The prevalence of the disease 'X' in a population is 30%. The diagnostic test for this disease has a specificity of 0.80 and a sensitivity of 0.90. What is the negative predictive value of the test?
questions.solution:
The negative predictive value of the above test is 95%.

For convenience, let us assume that the total population in this scenario is 100.

The prevalence of the disease is 30%. So the total number of people with the disease is 30(TP+FN) and disease-free(FP+TN) is 70.

Since sensitivity is 0.90, i.e. TP/(TP + FN) = 90%.

The total true positives (TP) = 90/100 x (TP+FN) = 90/100 x 30 = 27

False-negative(FN) = 30-27 = 3

Since specificity is 0.80, i.e. TN/(FP+TN) = 80%.

Total true negatives (TN) =(FP+TN) x 80/100 = 70 x 80/100 = 56

False-positive(FP) = 70-56 = 14

The given data is represented below:

 

Disease +

Disease -

Total

Test +

27 (TP)

14 (FP)

41

Test -

3 (FN)

56 (TN)

59

Total

30(TP+FN)

70(FP+TN) 

100

Negative predictive value (NPV) = TN/(FN + TN) x 100 = 56/59 = 0.949 = 95%.

An alternate formula(Bayes theorem) that can be used is NPV = (1-P) x Sp /[P x (1-Sn)] +[(1-P) x Sp]

Sn- Sensitivity, P- Prevalence, Sp- Specificity

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: The fasting blood glucose levels of a  population from two overlapping distributions are shown in the below graph. A test was done with the cutoff of 120mg/ dl for diagnosing diabetes. What does the shaded area represent?
questions.solution:
The shaded area represents the false positives (Non-diabetics incorrectly classified as diabetics). 

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: You are conducting a cohort study in a group of headload workers to identify the risk factors for developing low back pain in future. This type of study falls under which of the following?
questions.solution:
Cohort studies fall under non-experimental (observational) analytical studies.

Classification of epidemiological studies:

  1. Observational studies: allow nature to take its own course, the investigator measures but does not intervene. It is further classified into:
    • Descriptive studies: limited to describing the occurrence of a disease in a population.
    • Analytical studies: go further by analyzing the relationship between health status and other variables. It includes:
      • Ecological studies
      • Cross-sectional studies
      • Case-control studies
      • Cohort studies
  2. Experimental studies or interventional studies: it involves an active attempt to change a disease determinant or the progress of a disease, and is similar in design to experiments in other sciences.
    • Randomized controlled trials
    • Field trials
    • Community trials
